As she moved a part into position and began lowering the drill head, her right hand bumped the drill bit, which caught the fabric of the glove and pulled her right hand into the bit. The drill bit deeply lacerated her middle finger and partially amputated her pinky and index fingers.

On April 19, 2017, an employee was attempting to clear a plugged fiberglass tube from the sheet molding compound machine's glass cutter. While pulling the fiberglass through the tube, the employee's right middle fingertip struck the rotating cotton roller and was amputated. The machine was unguarded at the time of the incident.
An employee was operating a punch press when it malfunctioned and came down, amputating two fingers on his right hand.

An employee was on a ramp with a dolly when the dolly moved away from him and he fell down. His right hand was then caught between the dolly and the ramp, amputating his middle fingertip with no bone loss.
An employee amputated the right index fingertip while attempting to repair the balance on the forklift truck.

On April 19, 2017, at approximately 3:20 p.m., an employee was operating the chipper when a slab became hung up in the mouth of the chipper. The employee turned off the vibrating conveyor and gained access to the opposite side of the chipper. He pulled on the slab. When the slab came free, his hand was smashed between the slab and mouth of the chipper, amputating his right ring finger near the first knuckle.
An employee's finger was caught and amputated in a closing box truck door. The employee also suffered two broken fingers.
On April 20, 2017, an employee was performing maintenance on a conveyor belt when his right thumb was caught and amputated in the belt's chain and sprocket drive.
An employee was lifting a manhole cover when it slipped and amputated the right middle finger of another employee.
An employee was offloading dry fertilizer from a train car into a dry facility using an auger system when his foot and leg were pulled into the auger resulting in amputation of the leg.

An employee was replacing a broken bolt on a pneumatic cylinder of a 3,000 ton aluminum extrusion machine and amputated the right thumb at the first knuckle joint. The machine was guarded by distance with a guardrail system. The machine was running at the time.
An employee was attempting to unjam a wire cable from a winch when the employee's left hand entered the winch, amputating the middle fingertip.
An employee was operating a bone-in saw to cut meat when his left hand slipped off the meat and contacted the blade, amputating his left index fingertip.
An employee was cutting material and amputated his left ring finger.

An employee was working on the rig floor installing a lift cap into a mud tool. As the driller came up with the elevators his right middle finger was caught in between the elevators and the lift cap, partially amputating his finger.

A temporary employee was using a metal drum lift to lift a 55-gallon plastic drum to raise and tip the drum over and pour the suntan product mix into a container to be weighed. He placed his hand on the lift's clamp while the drum was in a vertical position. The drum slipped and his right index finger was caught between the top lip of the drum and the clamp resulting in the amputation of his right index fingertip.
On April 21, 2017, an employee was attempting to use a tool to remove a jam from a machine when the tool became caught in the machine's auger along with the employee's left index finger.
An employee sustained a partial amputation to the right thumb and index finger while cutting aluminum on a table saw.

Two employees were approximately 15 feet up in a scissor lift working on the motor for the overhead dock door at a customer's site. The overhead door activated and knocked the scissor lift over, causing one employee to fall out of the basket. One employee damaged his jaw, lost teeth, sustained rib injuries and potentially broke a leg. The second employee fractured a wrist. Both were hospitalized.
Two employees were moving a post tension machine to another location. The injured employee's left hand was inside the machine when it turned on resulting in a partial amputation of three fingers.
The employee was sanitizing a metal wire mesh conveyor belt. The employee dropped the wire mesh conveyor belt and it landed on his fingertip resulting in amputation of the fingertip.

While attempting to align fiber cement boxes weighing 300-400 lbs. on a forklift, the boxes shifted, catching the employee's left hand between the edges of the top and bottom boxes. The employee's left middle finger was amputated at the first knuckle joint and the left ring finger was crushed.
An employee was cleaning the ink reservoir on a printing press and the rag he was using was pulled into the rollers along with his hand. The tip of the employee's right pinky finger was amputated.

In the shelf line area, an employee was reaching over a conveyor belt to inspect the welded brackets on a piece of thin sheet metal when her hair got caught in the conveyor belt. The employee used her left hand to try to pull herself free when her left hand got caught in the conveyor belt resulting in amputation of the left pinky fingertip.

An employee was using a hoist to align a bolt in a front disc brake when he dropped the bolt. The employee went to pick it up and his right index finger slipped inside the bolt hole. The hoist was activated at the same time and the employee's index fingertip was amputated.
An employee was operating a pedal-activated chop saw to cut boards and amputated two left fingers.

An employee was using a portable cutting and beveling tool to cut a bevel on the end of a 24" schedule 120 pipe. The employee's gloved hand was caught and pulled between the beveling die and the pipe causing a partial amputation of the left index finger.

An employee was trouble shooting a planer that was making noise. The employee took off the guards and disassembled the planer. The employee plugged the motor in and while he was checking the bearings his right hand contacted the rotating planer blades resulting in multiple finger amputations.

An employee was installing a new gang saw when the employee's left hand was caught in the chain and sprocket resulting in a laceration and crushing injury to the index and middle fingers. The fingers were surgically amputated at the middle joint. The machine was not guarded or locked out at the time.

An employee was loading a 3 inch iron flow pipe (18 inches long) onto a trailer when his left ring finger became caught between the pipe and the trailer, resulting in amputation of his left ring fingertip.

An employee was loading his grocery-delivering cart at a customer's location when he lost his footing while tipping the cart over and fell backwards. The loaded cart fell on his right thumb amputating it above the first knuckle.
An employee was connecting a gooseneck trailer to a truck and manually adjusting the hitch onto the ball when the trailer dropped onto the ball, amputating the employee's fingertip.

An employee was checking a belt in an HVAC unit on a roof. The unit was shut off and locked out. However, 30 mile per hour winds caused the fan to move and pinch the employee's left pinky finger between the belt and the pulley, resulting in amputation of the left pinky fingertip.

An employee was servicing a molding press and was using a 4x4 to remove a press screw from inside the machine barrel. The 4x4 moved forward and pinned his right hand against the machine resulting in amputation of the right thumb tip.
An employee was operating a press when their right thumb became caught in the machine, resulting in amputation of the right thumb.
An employee was replacing a HVAC fan belt when their thumb became caught between the belt and pulley, resulting in amputation of the thumb.

Employees were depressurizing a level bridle when the hose between the bridle and the flare system broke releasing hydrofluoric acid (HF). The two employees were exposed to the chemical vapor resulting in injury to their eyes, facial skin and lungs. Both employees were hospitalized.
While working at a metal shear, an employee's middle fingertip contacted the point of operation and was amputated.
An employee was cutting a piece of cabinet wood on a table saw when his hand contacted the blade, resulting in amputation of his fingertips.
An employee was clearing a jam in a filler machine when his left index finger was partially amputated.
An employee was pressing a bearing when his finger became caught in the press machine, resulting in amputation of his left index fingertip.
An employee was operating a coil slitter when his finger became caught in the roller, resulting in amputation of his right index finger.
An employee was sanitizing the muffin machine auger when her right middle finger was caught in the running machine, resulting in a fingertip amputation.
An employee was changing slips on a rig when his hand became caught in the machine parts, resulting in amputation of part of his finger.
An employee was assembling a cooker valve when the employee's finger became caught between two valve parts, partially amputating the employee's right ring fingertip.

On April 27, 2017, an employee was using an overhead crane to lower a frame onto the frame table when his left middle finger was pinched between the strut stop and the frame, resulting in partial amputation.

An employee was tightening bolts on the back of a new blade for a wood chipper machine with an impact wrench when the employee's finger became caught between the blade and the washer on the back of the blade. The employee sustained amputation of the left index fingertip.
An employee was adjusting film on the back of the matrix machine when his left index finger was caught between a pulley and a belt. He sustained the amputation of his left index finger.
An employee was finishing a coil slitting operation when the coil rotated and caught his left hand between the coil and the divider, amputating his left pinky fingertip.
An employee was cutting a beam with a circular saw when the saw slipped and contacted his right hand. He sustained amputation of four fingers on his right hand.
An employee was delivering feed to a farm when the employee's glove and hand were caught on an auger attached to a trailer, resulting in partial amputation of the left index and middle fingers.
An employee was operating a table saw when his left hand contacted the blade, amputating three fingertips to the first knuckle.
An employee was loading steel beams when two of his fingers were smashed and amputated between two beams.

On April 28, 2017, an employee was setting up a die on a roller conveyor when the die shifted and rolled on the conveyor, pinching the end of his left middle finger. He sustained a crushing injury resulting in amputation of the left middle fingertip.

On April 28, 2017, an employee was using a rope to change the felt on a paper machine when his hand was caught in the nip point created by the rope and the shaft. He sustained amputation of the right middle and ring fingertips.

On April 28, 2017, an employee was mixing ingredients for soup when the mixer exit shoot became clogged. While loosening the clog, her glove became caught and she suffered a broken right middle finger and amputated right index fingertip.
An employee was manually feeding material into a punch press when the press amputated the employee's left second fingertip.
An employee was attempting to grab an operating circular saw when the employee's right middle fingertip was amputated.
An employee was trying to unjam the pins in a braid carrier machine when his right index finger was caught and amputated in the machine.
On 4/28/2017, an employee was operating a punch press when the employee's right index finger was caught and amputated in the machine.

An employee was placing a sheet of steel in a shear machine when the shear was activated via the foot pedal. The employee's right hand contacted the point of operation, amputating the index finger between the end of the nailbed and the first joint.
An employee was operating a grooving machine when his glove was caught in the machine and his right hand was pulled in, amputating his little finger. The machine was unguarded at the time.

An employee was operating a spreader/sprayer machine to apply fertilizers and herbicides to turf. He was attempting to repair/replace a belt in the machine when his right hand was caught and pulled into its pulley system, amputating his index fingertip. The machine was not locked/tagged out at the time.

An employee was dropping a fill cube into a basin when it was caught on bolts installed inside the basin. He pushed on the fill cube with his hand to free the fill cube. When the cube was freed it pinched his right hand between the casing panel and the basin, amputating his right index fingertip.
An employee was using a standing drill press to drill a round hole into aluminum when his gloved right hand was caught and his ring finger was pulled into the drill bit, amputating his fingertip.

An employee was operating a laminator that was on a cart when the cart hit a post, causing the laminator to come off the rails it sat on. The employee's right pinky finger was pinched and partially amputated between the frame of the cart and the laminator.
An employee was attempting to clear clogged material from a silo's inspection port when the rotary valve flights caught and amputated the fleshy pad of his left index finger.
An employee was inserting a metal spacer between two roll supports when the rolls closed hydraulically, crushing and amputating the tip of his right thumb.

An employee and two coworkers were manually tensioning a belt on a belt drive when his left thumb was pulled into the in-running nip point created between the belt and the sieve, amputating his thumb above the first knuckle. He was wearing leather gloves at the time of the incident.
An employee was going to cut a piece of flat metal and was using an air clamp to hold the metal in place when the employee's left thumb tip was caught and amputated.

An employee was waiting for potatoes to be graded (using a bulk grader) so that he could load them onto a tractor trailer when he noticed a bad potato on the conveyor. When he attempted to pull the bad potato out, his right index finger was caught in the conveyor's moving chain and sprocket, amputating it to the first joint.
On May 1, 2017, an employee's hand was caught and seriously injured in a small expander press that was activated via the foot control. The machine was unguarded at the time.
An employee was servicing an A/C unit with a clamp-on amp meter. He removed the cover to test the A/C when his left middle fingertip was caught and amputated (no bone loss) between a belt and pulley.
An employee was using a table saw to make prototype and merchandise products when the saw amputated the employee's left index finger.

An employee was using a vertical stacker to raise trusses. When the employee pushed the stacker bar over, it started to fall. As the employee tried to catch it, the stacker pinched and amputated the employee's fingertip.

An employee was carrying a conference tabletop up a stairwell with three other men. He put the table down to reposition it and his right index finger became caught. When he pulled his hand, his index fingertip was amputated.

An employee was installing a mixer with a coworker. His right hand was inside the pulley assembly, attempting to get the cable back on the pulley, when the up/down air lifter was actuated to relieve tension on the cable. The mixer then came down and amputated his right index fingertip between the knuckle and the nail.
An employee was getting out of a vehicle when a gust of wind blew the door shut on his finger, amputating the fingertip below the fingernail.

An employee was removing a stack of metal blank material from the blank stacker on the press. The riser that the blanks sit on had moved off the rollers while the blanks were stacking, therefore, the material would not roll freely. The employee attempted to move the blank material down by hand. The original stack fell striking his left ring finger resulting in a fingertip amputation.
An employee was operating a scissor lift and pinched the left ring finger at the middle phalanges between the lift's guardrail and a steel angle support resulting in amputation.

An employee was reaching for items that spilled out of a box on a moving conveyor belt when two of the employee's fingers were caught and crushed in the belt. The two fingers had to be medically amputated.
An employee's hand was caught between a pipe roller and a wire brush machine, smashing and partially amputating his right index fingertip.
An employee was using an end mill when it cut the employee's right index finger.
An employee was helping a chip saw operator clear the chip saw when he placed his right hand on the cutting head machine. The machine then amputated his right index fingertip without bone loss.
An employee suffered a fingertip amputation while operating an automotive lift.
An employee was using an industrial drill press when his glove became caught in the drill bit. The drill bit then amputated his left thumb.
Two of an employee's right-hand fingers were amputated by a conveyor belt and pulley system. The system was unguarded at the time.

An employee was trying to unhook a chain from a furnace lid that was stuck when the furnace operator pushed the lift button to the furnace lid and the chain caught the employee's left middle finger, amputating it.
An employee was opening the furnace and caught a finger in the chain and sprocket that controls the furnace door resulting in a right ring fingertip amputation.
An employee was working on a table saw cutting parts for door manufacturing when the saw blade partially amputated the employee's left ring fingertip.
An employee was training on how to operate a hydraulic piece of equipment when the employee's ring finger (left hand) was caught and partially amputated in the machine.
An employee was removing the expandable conveyor from storage and caught his right pinky finger in the conveyor belt resulting in a fingertip amputation.
An employee was bringing down boxes when a pallet fell on his face, lacerating his nose and requiring hospitalization.
An employee was pulling a cart through the door that had an automatic closer and her left hand was caught in the door jam resulting in a middle fingertip amputation.

An employee was using a pedestal sander to sand down the edges on a piece of metal using an 80 grit disc. While he was pushing the metal into the sander, the metal buckled and his left hand went into the face of the disc, amputating his left index fingertip.

An employee was standing on a truck step, inspecting the bays before making deliveries for the day. When he finished looking in the bay, he grabbed the strap of the door with his left hand and dismounted the step while his right hand was on the truck deck. The bay door closed on his right hand, partially amputating his middle fingertip, including the entire nail.
An employee suffered a pinky fingertip amputation.

An employee and coworker were attempting to replace an exterior panel on a cutting machine when the panel slipped and fell onto the injured employee's left middle finger, amputating the distal portion of the finger.
An employee was installing a 6" threaded metal fitting to a mud unit. The fitting slipped and the employee's left middle fingertip was crushed and amputated between the fitting and the mud unit.
An employee was laying down pipe. His left hand was on the pipe elevator. When the elevator opened, it pinched his left ring finger. His left ring fingertip had to be surgically amputated.
An employee was repairing a damaged pallet racking and pinched the right index finger between the concrete floor and a metal plate resulting in amputation of the finger above the first knuckle.
An employee suffered an amputation as a result of a workplace incident.
An employee suffered an amputation as a result of a workplace incident.
An employee was operating a table saw when the employee's finger contacted the saw blade, amputating the fingertip at the first knuckle.
An employee was using a portable table saw to cut a board when his left thumb contacted the blade and the thumb tip was amputated. The saw was unguarded at the time.
An employee was cleaning a press machine when the blade of a rotating wheel amputated his right index finger below the first distal knuckle and lacerated his right middle finger.
An employee was helping to rig a pipe with a sling to lift it. During the lift, the employee's right middle finger was caught between the pipe and sling, amputating his fingertip.

An employee was replacing a belt on a motor fan assembly when his right index finger was caught between the belt and the pulley, amputating the fingertip tip to the first knuckle. The belt was unguarded at the time.
An employee was un-jamming a machine while an air cylinder had residual air in it. The machine actuated, amputating the employee's right pinky fingertip.

An employee was sorting metals from non-ferrous material with a handheld magnet when his right thumb tip was crushed between the magnet and the metal wall of a bin, amputating part of his nail and soft tissue.

An employee was performing preventative maintenance on a machine and greasing a chain when a finger was caught in the machine's chain and sprocket resulting in partial amputation of the right thumb. The machine was not guarded at the time.

An employee had just installed a paint mixing paddle onto a drill. He then picked up the drill with his right hand while he held the paddle with his left. He contacted the trigger, engaging the drill. The drill turned quickly, wrapping this left hand around the drill. His middle and ring fingers were amputated below the distal joint.
An employee was using a wrench to remove a fitting from a pipe when his pinky finger was caught and amputated between the pipe and the wrench.

An employee was turning an elevated crane load (mill roll) by hand when his left hand was caught in the load. As he pulled his hand free, his left pinky finger suffered an avulsion. His fingertip had to be medically amputated.
An employee was preparing a crane and was placing a hydraulic pin in a hole when the hydraulic engaged and pinched his fingers. His left middle and ring fingertips had to be surgically amputated.

On May 8, 2017, around 11:15 a.m., an employee had just finished cutting a 6-foot piece of aluminum with an alligator shear when a piece of the metal spun into the air and amputated the first knuckle of his left ring finger.

An employee was attempting to clear a jam from a guarded straw processor machine when a sharp turn piece on the machine caught and partially amputated his left index finger. The machine was not locked/tagged out at the time.
An employee was cutting fiber board with a table saw when the blade amputated his thumb. The saw was not equipped with a stop at the time.

An employee was operating a pipe grooving machine to groove a steel pipe when his glove became caught and his hand was pulled in between the pipe and the back plate of the machine. His left middle, ring, and index fingers were partially amputated.

An employee was attempting to lubricate the chain and sprocket on a conveyor motor when he noticed dust and dirt behind the sprocket on the guard case. He wrapped a rag around his finger to wipe off the dirt. The rag and his right index finger were pulled into the sprocket, amputating his fingertip (no bone loss).

An employee was banding the coil on a recoiling machine when the coil came off of the track during the recoiling stage. The employee made some adjustments so the coil would line up correctly. A coworker then placed the separator down and used the manual control panel to finish the recoiling process. At that time, the employee's glove was caught between the lapse of the coil and was crushed by the separator, causing an amputation of the left ring finger.
On May 9, 2017, an employee was attempting to remove a piece of meat material from a chain drive guard when his left index fingertip was caught and amputated in the chain drive.
An employee was using a safety knife or a box cutter to cut rolls of film that were coming out of a machine when the blade amputated his left middle fingertip (skin only).
An employee was cutting meat with a band saw when his right index finger contacted the blade, amputating his fingertip above the knuckle.

An employee was cutting metal pieces in a shear that is operated with a foot control. While he was leaning forward to adjust a piece with his hand, his foot pushed down on the foot control and activated the shear, which then amputated his right middle fingertip.

An employee was on a ladder, removing a vice grip from a garage door to open it. When the vice grip came off, the door rolled open and knocked him off the ladder. His right thumb was pinched and amputated between the door and the track.

An employee was attempting to remove dried lead paste from a paddle at the outlet of a hopper when his glove became caught on a sprocket or drive chain on the hopper. His right middle finger was pulled approximately 1/2 inch into the chain, amputating it at the first knuckle. The chain was unguarded at the time.

On May 12, 2017, at 9:25 AM, an employee was operating a forklift to pick up a skid with two coils. As he backed up, the skid slid off of the forks. When the skid holding the material slid off the fork, it struck two employees. The first employee suffered a lower left leg amputation, while the second employee suffered a lower right leg amputation.

Two employees were attempting to change the die on the press brake when their hands were caught and crushed in the press brake, amputating their fingers. The machine was active at the time of the incident.
Two employees were cutting secondary cables in a pad-mounted electrical vault when an arc flash occurred, causing first and second degree burns.

Two employees were laying pipe underneath a joist when a third party hit the joist, causing it to fall on them. The first employee suffered a head injury, while the second suffered a broken arm, broken wrist, and bruised ribs.
Two employees were using a horizontal drying oven to dry aluminum sludge when they suffered burns to their arms and upper bodies due to a possible propane flashback.

Two employees were breaking out pipe for loading and transport at a shipyard dock. One of the breakout straps broke, causing the pipes to roll and strike the employees' legs. The first employee suffered a broken right ankle, and the second employee suffered a contusion on the left leg and a bruised right leg. They were both hospitalized for treatment.
Two employees were working in a ditch when the dirt wall collapsed on them. The first employee suffered a broken femur, tibia, pelvis, and T-3 vertebra. The second employee suffered a broken tibia.
Two employees were using a crane to load beams when a possible arc flash occurred. Both employees suffered an electrical shock.
Two employees were using a ripsaw when a spark or small fire ignited in the ripsaw's dust collection bag. A flash fire occurred, burning the upper body and arms of both employees.
Two employees were installing shingles on a new house when they were struck by lighting. They were hospitalized with burns.
Three employees were in a minivan on a non-commercial road when the vehicle went down an embankment. Two of the employees received multiple fractures and were hospitalized.
Two employees were in an open trench checking and making a grade when they were struck by a piece of rock. They both suffered leg injuries and were hospitalized.

Two employees were traveling in an all-terrain vehicle with coworkers when it flipped over. The first employee fractured the right ankle, requiring surgery. The second employee suffered head and facial lacerations.

Two employees were installing mesh wire from the fifth level of a scaffold. The planks tilted to one side of the scaffold and the employees fell 40 feet. They were hospitalized with a broken left arm and broken ribs.

Two workers were hospitalized with severe burns when a system malfunction in the industrial filter station caused rupture disks to burst and an overflow container to fill beyond its capacity ejecting "standard liquor," a hot liquid, onto nearby employees.

While closing the dump truck's rear gate, two employees' hands were injured when the gate closed on them. One employee had four fingers amputated as a result of the injuries. The other employee received crushing injuries to the hand.
Two employees were performing servicing work at a natural gas refrigeration plant when a fire erupted and seriously burned their backs.
Two employees were exposed to carbon monoxide from an open water fountain drain. They were hospitalized.
Two employees were working on a barge near a dock. They were receiving steel plates from the pier using a shore crane when they were struck by lightning. Both were hospitalized.
Two employees were working in an emergency room when they experienced difficulty breathing (from potential exposure to cleaning product) and required hospitalization.

On 9/15/2017, at approximately 3:10 p.m., two employees were in an articulating boom lift raising up along the side of a grain bin when they contacted overhead powerlines, receiving electrical shocks.
Two employees were using a ladder near a powerline to assess the condition of a roof when they received an electric shock, suffering burns on their feet and requiring overnight hospitalization.

Two employees were inside the top of a silo that was filled with corn silage. The employees were positioning an un-loader in the top of the silo to remove the silage. Another employee was positioned at the base of the silo. The employees heard a popping noise and the silo tipped over to the west. The two employees were free moving inside the silo cap and rode it down to the ground. The first employee suffered pelvic and rib injuries. The second employee suffered shoulder, rib, and lung injuries. Both were hospitalized.

Three employees were hospitalized for various injuries after being assaulted by a former employee. The former employee assaulted one employee with a hammer and beat another employee. The third injured employee was shot in the arm when he discovered the crime.

An employee was using a screwdriver to dislodge a cotton wad in the cotton feeder. A second employee came to see what was happening and to help. The first employee bumped the second employee, whose hand was then caught in the chain and sprocket of the running feeder. The second employee freed his hand and went to the office. During that time, the first employee's hand was also caught in the chain and sprocket. They both suffered lacerations and smashed fingers. The first employee's middle or ring finger was surgically amputated. The second employee's forefinger was surgically amputated.

On 11/09/2017, an employee was operating a blow mold machine when it jammed. The employee was trying to unjam it when the machine crushed and lacerated the right index finger. On 11/21/2017, an employee was operating a capper machine when it jammed. She was trying to unjam it when her sleeve was caught on a moving part, pulling her right arm into the machine and fracturing it. 

Note to user: This record contains two separate events that were reported simultaneously to OSHA by the employer.  These events are captured as one report.
Two employees where painting in a scissor lift when they fell. The first employee fell on his back while the second employee fell face down on the floor. Both were hospitalized.
On 11/16/2017, two employees were attempting to clear a hydrate formation in a gas pipeline at a tank battery when flammable gases and vapors ignited, causing significant burns to both employees.
Employees were erecting a pump-jack scaffold when two employees received an electric discharge from a powerline, requiring hospitalization.
Two employees were attempting to light a pilot light on an incinerator when the gases ignited and back-flashed on them. They sustained facial and hand burns.

Two employees were removing an old process line that contained residual dibenzoyl peroxide when the process line exploded. The first employee suffered a forehead cut, mangled right hand, lower arm amputation, and internal injuries due to piping puncturing the stomach/chest area. The second employee was hit in the face by a pipe, suffering a broken jaw.
Two employees were working in a trench when a backhoe bucket rolled into the trench and struck them. They suffered a broken ankle and shoulder injury, requiring hospitalization.
An employee was working from an elevated lift platform when the lift rolled over, causing the employee to fall to the ground and suffer blunt force trauma. The employee was hospitalized.

Three employees were using a cleaning vehicle to clean a bay floor inside a garage. The employees felt nauseous, lightheaded and weak after running the gasoline-powered cleaning equipment for approximately two hours with the garage doors closed. Two employees were hospitalized for carbon monoxide poisoning.

Two employees were disconnecting an ammonia sparger tube from an NF3 reactor when their hands were exposed to hydrofluoric acid. They suffered chemical burns and blistering on their hands and fingers, requiring hospitalization.

On January 19, 2018, at approximately 10:09 a.m., two employees were replacing a gasket on a sight glass when an arc flash erupted from the transformer, causing second degree burns to their face, head, and hands.

Two employees were performing maintenance and troubleshooting on the B side of a reactor catalyst feed system when the tubing failed on the A side and caused an explosion of hydrocarbon products. Both employees received thermal burns and were hospitalized.

Two employees were part of a crew performing a re-roofing job (TPO type roofing work) at night. The building was 22.7 feet high (at the highest elevation) and was a single-story warehouse-type building with two roof elevations. The employees were on the highest roof elevation when a rough terrain forklift with a material handling wooden box on the forks was used to remove debris from the roof. The box was raised to the roof and the two employees got in the box to get a ride back to the ground. While they were in the box, it became dislodged and fell to the ground. One employee sustained head and body trauma, while the second suffered a fractured wrist. Both were hospitalized.
Employees were cleaning out a shaker trough with a pressure washer when hydrogen sulfide gas released from the shaker. Two employees were hospitalized due to gas exposure.

An employee was using a spray wand connected to a hot water pressure washer to open up a frozen produce water tank. The produce water vented hydrocarbon vapors near the hot water pressure washer causing a fire. Two employees received second and third degree burns to the face, neck and hands.

Two employees were installing a new arm on a 200 foot power pole in a 295-foot aerial lift. The lift shifted and the employees fell out of the basket. The employees were using fall protection and suffered traumatic injuries from the fall protection equipment.

Two employees were observing a crew post-tensioning a rod while standing on a bridge structural beam when the beam collapsed. They struck the ground, suffering fractures and lacerations that required hospitalization.
Two employees were cutting concrete with a power saw when they were overcome by carbon monoxide poisoning.

Two employees were inspecting an electrical cabinet after pulling new cable into a 6.9 KV lift pump breaker cubicle when an arc flash occurred. The first employee suffered burns on the face, chest, and arms. The second employee suffered burns on the face, but mostly on the arms and hands. Both were hospitalized.
An employee was unscrewing bolts and the ceiling collapsed. The employee sustained a broken wrist, arm, and collarbone.
Two employees slipped and fell on ice in the parking lot, fracturing their ankles and requiring hospitalization.

Two employees were setting wooden trusses when the trusses collapsed on them and the employees fell to the concrete floor below. They were both hospitalized for fractured bones, concussions and contusions.
Two employees were collecting a catalyst sample from a tank when the chemicals splashed them.  They were hospitalized with burns on their face and hands.

On March 29, 2018, two employees were using a propane-powered forklift to treat seed in a seed warehouse when they became ill. They were both hospitalized with carbon monoxide poisoning from the forklift.

Employee #1 was shutting down the system where molten resin goes through a filter prior to being cooled and processed on the belt. The employee tried to clean the material from the filter using nitrogen. The O-ring on the filter failed, allowing hot molten resin to spray out. The employee moved away from the area thinking that the pressure was relieved from the filter. When he returned with another employee, more molten resin sprayed out, burning both employees.
During a training exercise, a CS gas canister prematurely exploded and injured two employees, who suffered a broken femur and chest laceration.

Three employees were removing sand bags after installing a steel pole when a digger truck boom contacted electrical wiring (phases), exposing them to an electrical current that burned them. Two employees were hospitalized.

An employee was mixing a batch of raw materials under a hood using a hot plate and a 2-gallon steel pot when flames emerged from the pot. A second employee, who was also working under the hood on another batch of product, responded and placed a lid over the pot to suppress the flames. Shortly thereafter, an energy release occurred, creating a larger flame and a pressure wave that knocked the pot onto the floor. Some of the pot's contents landed on the first employee's body and clothes and the second employee's hand. The first employee received third degree burns to both hands and second degree burns to the arms, face, and stomach. The second employee received second degree burns to the right hand.

Two employees were working in a vacant apartment. One employee had a gun and was showing it to the other employee when the gun went off. Both employees were shot, the first in the hand and the second in the stomach; both were hospitalized.

Employees were releasing pressure from a well, moving lines from one well to another and placing a cap on the well-pumping lines. A crown valve was open and blew up. One employee sustained a broken right forearm, a second employee sustained a head injury and a third employee sustained an injury requiring surgery.

Two maintenance employees received second degree burns on their torso, legs and arms while troubleshooting a pump that moves ambient air, water and paper stock through a sewer/pipe system. The line/pump was plugged and the pump was shut down. After a period of time where the pump was running (not moving water and paper stock) and plugged, the ambient water and paper stock heated up. The maintenance personnel did not realize that the water had heated (temp unknown at time) and proceeded to open the inspection port. As the inspection port was opened, a sudden release of hot water/paper stock sprayed the two maintenance personnel.

Two employees were dismantling forms from a cap on a bridge column. The concrete forms shifted and collapsed onto both employees. The first employee was hospitalized for a broken pelvis. The second employee was hospitalized for a broken jaw.

Three employees were on a paint truck applying paint stripping on the highway when a semi-trailer struck the rear of the paint truck flipping it over. Two employees were hospitalized for a concussion, brain bleeding and broken ribs.

A RackMasters employee and a temporary employee were in a scissor lift at an elevation of approximately 20 feet, using a hand-held tool to unscrew angle joints and dismantle a rack. They were removing the final piece of the rack, which was against the wall of the facility (almost flush with the wall), when the rack became loose, fell, and hit the scissor lift. The scissor lift then fell over and the two employees jumped when it was about 2 feet from the ground. The employees suffered a spinal fracture and fractured arm.

Five employees were transported to the hospital and two were admitted. The employees suffered from some type of a reaction during a monthly birthday celebration where fake mustaches were worn. One employee had difficulty breathing and eventually stopped breathing. Another employee suffered a seizure.
Two employees were shutting down equipment to move a condenser's breaker box from one building to another when an arc flash occurred, burning their left and right arms.
Two employees were exposed to chemical vapors being emitted from a chemical tote, suffering eye, mucous membrane, and lung irritation. They were hospitalized.

An employee was operating a hot glue gun machine while assembling a steel door when the employee noticed an odor. A second, maintenance employee was called to inspect the ventilation system in the area. The two employees were hospitalized due to respiratory issues.

On 7/26/2018, an employee's finger was caught in an auger, resulting in a right middle finger amputation at the first digit. On 7/28/2018, an employee's fingers were caught in a belt and pulley powered by an electric motor, resulting in an amputation of the left index and middle fingers at the second knuckle. This record contains two separate events that were reported simultaneously to OSHA by the employer. These events are captured as one report.
An employee was unloading asphalt milling onto a state highway from a dump truck. The dump truck rolled over onto the driver's side and the employee sustained fractured ribs and a punctured lung.
Two employees became ill while removing asbestos tile. They were hospitalized.
Two employees were using a propane saw when they suffered carbon dioxide poisoning. They were hospitalized.

On August 6, 2018, at approximately 12:16 PM, a hydraulic line located at the 3,000-ton press shear station unexpectedly released pressurized hydraulic fluid. The hydraulic fluid traversed to a separate operation next to the press and landed on a hot part (small ring expander), resulting in a flash fire. As a result, two employee suffered second and third degree burns to their hands and face, requiring hospitalization.

Employees were running a machine (controlled atmosphere plasma spray). The process involves titanium powder. They noticed some sparking on the piping that goes to the dust collector and they started wiping the residue off the piping. A cap on a second set of piping was removed to clean the piping which introduced air into the piping and a flashback occurred. Both employees were hospitalized for burns.
Two employees were welding on a storage tank when the insulation caught fire and the employees fell 30 feet.

Two employees were using survey equipment to set a center line measurement in a cross-over median section of the roadway when a vehicle drove across the roadway at a hard 45-degree angle and struck both employees. One employee suffered a knee injury and abrasions, while the other employee suffered a clavicle fracture and laceration.

Three employees were performing maintenance on a pipeline by using a pig to clean the line when a hose connected to the pressurized line flew back and struck two employees. The air from the hose injured the third employee. Two of the employees were hospitalized with broken bones and abrasions.

Between around 4:30 and 4:45 p.m., two employees were motoring a skiff down a river when the skiff hydroplaned and struck the shoreline. The employees were both injured: one suffered upper body injuries (suspected broken ribs) and a concussion and the other suffered facial and leg injuries. Both were hospitalized.

Three employees were cutting bolts off a man way using a grinder.  Sparks from the grinder caused a flash fire and the employees were burned. Two employees were hospitalized. The third employee was treated and released.
Two employees were trimming trees and bushes in a mobile home park when they both had heart attacks due to possible oleander bush poisoning. They were both hospitalized.

Two employees were installing a jumper between two power lines from an aerial lift when an arc flash occurred. The first employee suffered a second degree burn on his left thigh, and the second employee received a first degree burn to his left arm. They were both hospitalized.
Two employees were cutting with a saw when carbon monoxide built up. They suffered carbon monoxide poisoning and were hospitalized.
Two employees were working around an extrusion machine when it overheated and sprayed molten aluminum on them. They were hospitalized with burns.

Two employees were working in a designated paving area. The first employee was operating an asphalt paver while a second employee was walking to the left of the paver, examining the paving, when a publicly owned vehicle veered into the designated paving area and struck the two employees. The first employee suffered fractures to the left leg, while the second employee suffered multiple fractures to the body.
Two employees suffered carbon monoxide poisoning from a generator.

Two employees were driving on a lease road, hauling a pump. An antenna on the pump got caught on an overhead electrical wire, directing energy to the truck. One employee suffered an electrical burn, as well as a sprained ankle when he jumped out of the truck; the other suffered a shoulder injury when he jumped out of the truck and rolled on the ground.

Two employees were trying to start up a plastics extruder after a maintenance shutdown. As they tried to resolve an overpressurization problem, molten plastic began spraying from the screen changer vents. Both employees suffered burns to the head, torso, and upper extremities. They were hospitalized.
Employees were replacing fuse cutouts from an underground riser. An impact gun touched a fuse cutout, causing an arc flash that burned two employees.
While fighting a rooftop fire, two employees slipped on melted tar. The tar got on their hands and arms, causing second-degree burns.

Employees were finishing concrete on the second floor of a deck. An employee was about to mop the concrete with a 10-foot pole. Noticing that the top of the pole was about 6-8 feet from a power line, he moved to grab the pole; he then felt a shock and fell backwards onto another employee. Both received electrical burns and were hospitalized.
Two employees were attempting to light flat-top grill pilot lights with long butane lighters when a burst of flame from the grill burned the employees. They were both hospitalized.

On October 27, 2018, at approximately 9:15 PM, a crew of five employees was working on a drilling rig when the traveling block hit the crown, which caused the travel block to fall to the rig floor. One employee was struck by debris from the damaged rig and suffered a fractured neck, broken left arm, and two broken ribs. Another employee jumped away from the rig structure and fell to the ground below resulting in a left foot amputation.

Employees were breaking the concrete median of a road under construction (widening) with a jack hammer. The jack hammer struck an electrical duct bank causing an arc flash. Two employees were burned and hospitalized.
An employee slipped off a ladder onto a second employee that was holding the ladder before hitting the ground. Both employees were hospitalized with fractures.
Employees were using a trencher to dig when the trencher chain struck a natural gas line and exploded. Two employees suffered burns.

On November 21, 2018, two employees entered a trench to manually locate a fiber optic cable that had been cut. The trench was 9'8" deep and 5'6" wide and had no protective systems in place.  At approximately 8:30 p.m. the east wall of the trench caved in, trapping both employees. Both employees were hospitalized for nerve damage to their lower extremities.
Employees were loading pigs onto a pig launcher when a flash fire occurred, burning two employees. Fire-retardant clothing was worn at the time of the incident.

An employee was driving a car and ran into the back of another car that a second employee was cleaning. The employee who had been driving was dazed and short of breath. The second employee sustained injuries to the back and neck. Both were hospitalized.
Two employees were at a roadside, digging pole holes using hydro pressure. The boom on a truck got close to electrical lines, which arced; the employees were shocked. Both were hospitalized.

At about 12:40 p.m. on December 5, 2018, two employees were rolling a starter on a compressor that involved inserting a large breaker into a switchgear. An arc flash burned both employees, and both were hospitalized.

Two employees were cleaning a concrete form. It fell over and they both jumped off of the form. One employee's leg was hit and fractured. The second employee was pinned between two concrete forms and sustained broken bones and internal injuries. Both were hospitalized.

A temporary employee was manually removing steel rings from production equipment when the steel rings slipped. The employee tried to catch the rings as they fell and suffered a severe laceration on his right hand requiring hospitalization. 

An employee was repairing a dock door and replacing the panel when the cable and the panel popped back and struck him in the face. The employee was hospitalized for a fractured jaw.

Note to user: This record contains two separate events that were reported simultaneously to OSHA by the employer.  These events are captured as one report.
A transport platform fell about 15 feet to the street below during dismantling operations, injuring five employees. Two were hospitalized for broken bones, bruises and contusions.
Two workers received flash burns to their faces and hands while bleeding a residential gas line. The fire was ignited by the customer's cigarette.

Two employees were unloading a slab of granite weighing about 1,000 pounds from a fifth-wheel trailer to an A-frame on the ground, using a clamp attached to a rented forklift. The A-frame shifted and the slab tipped over. One of the employees suffered a broken tibia and fibula, requiring surgical repair and pins; the other suffered several broken bones in the leg, as well as a possible broken hip and shoulder.
Two employees were installing conduit when they experienced headaches and felt unwell. Both employees were hospitalized with carbon monoxide exposure/poisoning.

Two employees were helping welders by holding a 16" flange when a flash fire occurred. The first employee suffered a puncture wound from a vent pipe and burns to the face. The second employee suffered burns to the back of his neck, his back, and his right arm.
Six employees on night shift were attempting to put out a fire in one of the buildings when they were overcome by the heavy smoke. Two of the employees were hospitalized.

Two employees were loading a gas furnace with electrical connectors. They were near the controls to close the furnace door when an explosion occurred. They sustained second and third degree burns to the face, neck, and hands. One employee also sustained burns to the legs.

Three employees were working on the roof of a newly constructed residential home when the brace holding up the roof over the back patio gave way and the patio roof collapsed. The employees fell 21 feet and impacted the frozen ground. All three employees sustained multiple cuts, bruises and fractures to their lower extremities, specifically their feet and legs. Two of the three employees were hospitalized.

Employees were installing trusses and were tied off to a truss when a crane with another truss struck the truss where the employees were tied off. The employees and the truss fell and suffered injuries requiring hospitalization. One employee suffered a fractured skull. The second employee fractured ribs.
Two employees were using a propane torch to thaw a valve on a water tanker trailer. There was an explosion and both employees were burned.

Employees were pulling electrical wires to facilitate the installation of a new air compressor. While  pulling wires, the wall/barrier inside of an electrical cabinet contacted buss bars located in an adjacent cabinet creating an electrical arc blast. One Cayuga Milk Ingredients, LLC employee and two contractor employees were burned on the hands, neck, back and face. Two of the employees were hospitalized.

Three employees were walking down the stairs. The stairs collapsed and two of the employees were injured. They suffered multiple fractures, contusions, and lacerations to the legs, arms, ankles, back and chest.
A chlorine spill occurred at the worksite and the chlorine fumes caused respiratory distress for two employees.

On March 15, 2019, at 1530, two employees noticed smoke from the sawdust bin. The two employees attempted to move the sawdust in the bin to the ground via an auger system.  Thirty minutes later, the employees opened the lower hatch. A blast of fire shot from the hatch, severely burning the two men. The first employee suffered burns on the neck, face, and hands. The second employee suffered burns on the chest and stomach area.
Three employees were power washing when the washer caught fire. Two of the employees were hospitalized with burns.
Two employees were painting street lines in a middle lane work zone when they were struck by a vehicle, suffering head injuries.
Three employees got into an altercation; one was stabbed in the arm and another suffered a broken jaw.

Two maintenance workers were servicing an electronic fill button on a nearby 12 to 17 percent sodium hypochlorite chemical day tank. A 1-inch chemical line became dislodged and sprayed both employees, causing chemical burns on their chests, torsos, and arms. Both employees were hospitalized.

An employee was using a handheld propane torch to heat the end of another tool. The employee turned the propane torch off and set it on a truck. The truck caught on fire. The employee and another employee tried to suffocate the fire, then used fire extinguishers to put the fire out. Both employees sustained burns to the right arm and face. One employee also sustained a burn to the back. They were both hospitalized.
Employee 1 was hospitalized after becoming dizzy and having a headache during SWAT training. Employee 2 was hospitalized after completing SWAT training having possibly suffered a seizure.

An employee was attaching a detonation cord to a power source when a static charge set off a length of the detonation cord with three charges attached. Two employees were struck by multiple explosive fragments in the arms and legs, requiring hospitalization.
Three employees were hospitalized for burns after a propane gas explosion occurred.

Two employees were preparing to pour concrete in the tie beams. Both employees were holding the concrete pump hose when the hose kinked and swung knocking both employees off the tie beam onto the plywood floor. One employee was hospitalized for a concussion. The second employee was hospitalized for a fractured tailbone.

Employee 1 was working on a piece of equipment when the equipment lost power. Employee 2 was working in the precision sheet/pickle room. Employee 1 checked the electrical panel for burned out fuses. Employee 1 donned arc flash gear and retrieved a meter to test the circuits. While testing the leads of the meter, the employee contacted vice grips that were located in the panel. The vice grips toppled into the panel creating an arc flash. Employee 2 was processing titanium sheets for the pickle line when the power shutdown. Employee 2 was exposed to nitric oxide and hydrofluoric acid. Employee 1 sustained second degree burns to five percent of the body and Employee 2 inhaled nitric oxide and hydrofluoric acid.

Employees were cutting heating coil pipes using an electric reciprocating saw inside a starboard cargo tank on a barge. Gasoline vapors ignited and employees received first, second, and third degree burns. Two employees were hospitalized.

An employee turned on a process pump inside a fish processing plant. The pump cap housing blew off causing hot water to forcibly flow out of the pump and strike the employee in multiple areas on the front of his body. As the employee turned away from the hot water, he was struck in multiple areas on the back of his body and knocked to the ground momentarily. Hot water also struck a second employee on the back while running away from the area.

Two employees were pulling a messenger cable from one utility pole to another when the messenger cable contacted an adjacent power line. Both employees suffered electrical burns to the hands and arm and were hospitalized.

Two employees were coming down a ladder when one slipped and started to fall. He grabbed the other employee in an attempt to stop himself and pulled him down with him to the concrete floor. The first employee suffered bruising to the ribs, shoulder, and neck. The second employee suffered a fractured wrist and pelvis.
Employees were using a tapping machine to perform a hot tap on a natural gas line. As the employees began a three-way bypass, a flash fire occurred. Two of the employees were hospitalized for burns.

Employees of ExxonMobil Global Projects along with another contractor employee were in an office trailer conducting office duties when a tornado hit the trailer causing destruction of the trailer and laceration and fracture injuries to the personnel inside.

Two employees were in a scissor lift lowering support pipes down. As they began lowering one of the pipes, the bottom of the pipe slid into the scissor lift, causing the lift to tip over. Both employees jumped out of the lift (approximately 3 feet) before the lift collapsed to the ground. The first employee suffered a broken hip, a broken tailbone, bruises, and cuts. The second employee suffered a broken pelvic bone, a fractured left elbow, bruises, and scrapes.

Employees were providing customer care in an assisted living facility when a gastrointestinal virus broke out among customers and employees. Multiple employees experienced stomach and other health effects. Two employees were hospitalized.
Two employees were using conductive tools to install a PLC when they came into contact with an energized component. An arc flash occurred, causing second and third degree burns to the employees.
Two employees were working out of a bucket truck moving a service line higher up an existing utility pole. Both employees were shocked and hospitalized.
Two maintenance employees were investigating a water leak on a furnace when the furnace exploded, causing hand, neck, knee, and leg burns to both employees.
While removing a power swivel and tank from a drill site, two employees sustained chemical burns on their legs from an unknown caustic chemical.

Two employees were traveling in a UTV on a gravel road. The UTV slipped off the road. While it was being maneuvered back onto the road it slipped and hit a tree. The driver was ejected and suffered a broken femur and knee damage; the passenger suffered fractures to the ankle and arm and a head laceration. Both employees were hospitalized.
Two employees were shot by an active shooter in a store.
Two employees servicing an ATS terminal for a load bank test with a generator were exposed to an arc flash when opening the terminal cover. The employees suffered dermal burns.

Two employees were working on an exterior light fixture from a scissor lift 8 feet above the ground, right outside of the door to an airplane hangar. The hangar door was opened, knocking the scissor lift over. The two employees fell to the ground, suffering injuries including a broken jaw and arm fractures. Both employees were hospitalized.
Two employees were operating a machine next to storage totes stacked on each other when a tote fell approximately 16 feet and struck the employees. They suffered head and back injuries.

Two employees were using a scissor lift to spray-paint and back-roll an exterior wall. The scissor lift was extended to approximately 18 feet when it tipped over. Both employees on the lift fell to the ground with the lift. The lift was operating on asphalt at the time of the incident. The first employee suffered a broken left leg, broken right arm, and three fractured vertebrae. The second employee suffered a broken pelvis and a neck injury. Both employees were hospitalized.
Two employees were performing fabrication work on an existing pipe when the valve was inadvertently hit, spraying hot water on and burning the employees.

Two employees were removing a flange blank from a pipeline when they were sprayed by a 50% sodium hydroxide caustic solution. They were hospitalized with third degree chemical burns to the eyes and face.

Two employees were working in the store behind the counter when a car crashed through the front of the store and hit both employees. The employees were both hospitalized. One employee sustained fractured cervical vertebrae and facial lacerations requiring stitches. The second employee sustained a broken clavicle and a broken nose.
During a joint operation, a marine interdiction agent and a border patrol agent suffered smoke inhalation due to a boat fire.
Two laboratory employees were re-stocking chemicals on shelves. While moving a 4-liter glass bottle of acetonitrile the bottle dropped and broke, splashing them with acetonitrile.
A crew was using a pump to circulate fluids to a tank when there was a release from a well and a flash fire occurred. Two employees suffered burns to the face and body, requiring hospitalization.

At 7:27 AM, two maintenance workers were working in an aerial lift that was 27 feet off of ground. They were servicing an overhead crane. Another overhead crane ran into the aerial lift, tipping it over. The two maintenance workers were hospitalized with fractures to their backs and other injuries.

Four employee were pouring a 320" copper stock.  A hose failed which caused the ram of the casting unit to drop during the pouring process. The falling of this ram, which was controlled by the caster, allowed molten copper to come in contact with steam inside the pit that is filled with water. This caused a violent reaction/explosion. All four employees received burns to their arms, body, and face when they were sprayed with molten copper.

Two employees were rigging up centrifugal equipment. One employee was on the solids control equipment stand when it gave way, causing him to fall and sustain three fractured ribs and a punctured left lung. The other employee was on the ground near the stand when it collapsed, resulting in a fracture to his lower left leg.
An 18-inch pipe rolled off the forks of a loader when the clamps were lowered. Two employees' legs were pinned between the pipes.

Three employees were detaching an elevated walkway from a tank battery. After being cut, the walkway gave way while two of the employees were on it, and they fell about 15 feet to the ground. One of them suffered a compound fracture to the right femur and a concussion. The other suffered a crushed left heel.

Three employees were removing pins from gang forms in order to lower a form. When the upper pin was removed, the form fell forward, striking and landing on top of the employees. One employee received serious back injuries, while another employee suffered contusions to his upper body and a broken left ankle. They were both hospitalized.
Two employees were attempting to move a pallet when the pallet fell on top of them. One employee sustained a broken ankle and the second employee sustained severe knee injuries.

Two employees were working from mobile scaffolding when it collapsed. Together, the employees suffered multiple fractures and were hospitalized. One employee also suffered a concussion. The second employee is paralyzed from the neck down.

Employees were performing normal daily tasks within the rendering department when a natural gas explosion occurred in the furnace of the blood dried system. Two employees were hospitalized with burns and other injuries.

Two employees were transferring pre-cast concrete using a 7-ton overhead crane. The wire rope broke and the hoist block fell onto the employees. Employee 1 had two toes amputated from the left foot. Employee 2 suffered crushing injuries to both legs resulting in amputation of both legs.
Two employees were removing a steel plug from a pump. Hot asphalt sprayed their faces, causing burns.
Two employees were phasing out a new run of cable when an arc flash occurred, causing burns to their faces that required hospitalization.
While working in a tunnel, two employees suffered flash burns from underground equipment.
As they were leaving a control room, two employees fell 30 feet through a floor opening immediately outside the door to the concrete below and were hospitalized.

Two employees were installing a blank line inside of a coke oven when the emissions line water seal broke, exposing the employees to the coke oven emissions. The employees experienced elevated carboxyhemoglobin from carbon monoxide overexposure and were hospitalized.

Two employees were troubleshooting the starter on a forklift in the maintenance area. While both employees were on opposite ends of the forklift, the second employee pulled the connection tube on the forklift tank. A flash fire occurred. The first employee suffered second degree burns to the face. The second employee suffered second degree burns to the hand/finger and a first degree burn to the forearm. Both were hospitalized.
Two employees were mixing mildew cleaner when sodium hypochlorite and phosphoric acid were mixed, creating chlorine gas. Both employees were hospitalized with inhalation injuries.
Two employees were staging material for an upcoming job when an active vent line above them had a release of steam. They both received second degree burns and were hospitalized.
Employees were working in the sterilization department. A motor which controlled the ventilation of ethylene oxide failed. Six employees were hospitalized for exposure to ethylene oxide.

Two employees were opening the top hatch on sulfur rail cars to vent them when the employees were overcome by hydrogen sulfide gas. They were both hospitalized. The first employee suffered pulmonary edema (chemical) and the second employee suffered hemorrhaging in the eyes due to breathing stress.
Two employees were installing a service panel cover when the cover contacted live circuits, causing electrical burns to both employees' hands (one hand each).
Two employees were burned while they were cleaning out a tank when a spontaneous combustion occurred.
Three employees were attempting to fix a leaking valve on a tanker truck that contained butane when a flash fire ignited, causing burns to 90 percent of the employees' bodies.

Two employees were on a lift torch-cutting an old connection plate off of a concrete beam and preparing to weld a new connection plate on when a concrete beam weighing approximately 68,500 pounds hit the lift and collapsed the basket.  The employees fell approximately 21 feet with the basket to the ground, sustaining a spinal injury, broken ribs, and a facial injury.

On February 5, 2020, at approximately 5:00 p.m., two employees were using acetylene torches to dismantle an industrial tank. A small piece of steel fell to the floor, creating a small spark that resulted in a flash fire. The first employee sustained first and second degree burns. The second employee sustained first and second degree burns and a possible lung injury. Both were hospitalized.
Employees were using steam to soften and unclog an asphalt blow line. The asphalt released under pressure and burned two employees' arms and hands. They were hospitalized.

Employees were operating a baggage tractor on a service road. The tractor made contact with an aircraft's left wing and the seat of the tractor was ripped off. The employees were thrown to the ground. Two employees were hospitalized with injuries including a chipped tooth, bruises and abrasions, a dislocated hip, a fractured humerus bone, and a laceration to the left knee.

Two employees were cooking in the kitchen when they became dizzy and faint and had headaches. The employees were transported to the hospital for treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning due to a malfunctioning exhaust hood.
Two employees went to service a car and the car ran over them. One employee was hospitalized for a broken leg. The second employee was hospitalized for a broken hip.

Three employees were tying up a cruise vessel when the vessel tightened one of the ropes, causing it to pop and strike the three employees. Two of the employees were hospitalized. Employee 1 was hospitalized with a fractured left index finger and left forearm. Employee 2 was hospitalized with multiple fractures on the left arm. Employee 3 sustained bruises to the right side of the body.

An employee was cleaning the yard and burning trash. An empty barrel that had held flammable material exploded on the trash pile. The employee suffered second-degree burns to the hands and face, and another employee from a different company also received hand and facial burns. Both employees were hospitalized.

An employee was struck by a forklift while standing in an aisle. The employee landed on storage racks. The forklift operator fell out of the forklift and was struck by the forklift and also landed on storage racks. Between them, the two employees suffered multiple facial and skull fractures, a concussion, and internal bleeding.

Two employees were digging and dewatering an excavation when one of them came into contact with a live underground power line. One employee suffered an electric shock and left hand burns; the other was also shocked. Both employees were hospitalized.
While moving furniture, two employee's fell from the second-floor balcony to the ground level when the railing gave way. The employee's were hospitalized with trauma to the back, head and face.

Employees were troubleshooting a PSV that was lifting prematurely. A release of hydrocarbon/hydrogen caused an explosion and fire. One employee suffered burns to the face. A second employee struck a rail during egress as a result of the pressure wave and suffered a fractured kneecap. Both employees were hospitalized.

Two employees were working on a 16-inch plastic water pipe, drilling for a saddle tap when the pipe exploded. One employee suffered an amputation of the right arm, a laceration to the right leg, and the loss of the right eye. The second employee suffered lacerations to the legs and sand in the eyes.
Two employees were sitting at a table outside their work building, next to the parking lot. A patient's vehicle struck the employees, who suffered fractures to the lower extremities and head trauma.
An excavator's boom swung and struck two employees. Between them, they suffered a broken collar bone, 15 broken ribs, and a punctured lung.
Two electrical workers suffered a 480-volt shock. They were hospitalized.

Two employees were installing vent pipe and supports on top of a bulk storage tank. There was an explosion in the tank causing the employee working on the tank roof to fall from the tank to the ground. The employee was hospitalized for a fractured shoulder. The second employee was in an aerial lift at the roof line when the tank exploded. The second employee did not fall, but sustained flash burns to the face and arms.

Two employees were standing in a loading area and operating an overhead crane with a remote when a set of PBR aluminum steel sheets fell from the crane and landed on the employees. The first employee suffered a forehead laceration. The second employee suffered a broken right leg.
Two employees fell off of scaffolding while installing drywall. They were hospitalized with broken legs.
Two employees were working inside of a water tower to erect scaffolding when they fell approximately 40 feet to the ground.
Two employees were assaulted by a customer in a cell phone store, suffering bruises.

Two employees (one driving, one a passenger) were transporting a load of steel reinforcement on a rough-terrain flatbed truck. The truck rolled down a hill and overturned. The driver suffered a broken heel and the other employee's foot was broken.

Employees were pulling cable strands with a rating of 5000 pounds. While they were tightening the cable on the right side of the street, there was some slack in the cable on the left side of the street. A tractor trailer pulled out of an industrial park and snapped the cable. The cable swung towards the bucket truck causing employee 1, who was wearing a harness, to jump out of the bucket truck to avoid being hit by the cable. Employee 1 sustained a fractured rib and a back injury. The cable then swung through some trees and hit employee 2, who was on the ground. Employee 2 sustained a leg injury.

Two employees were doing monthly preventive maintenance/inspection on a natural gas boiler system. A fire ignited in the system; one employee was burned on the back and side of the head, and the other suffered second-degree burns on his face, arms, and hand.

Employees of Sundown Operating, Inc., and Axis Energy Services, LLC were working at an old oil/gas well plugging the well and getting ready to rig down. The Axis Energy Services employee was working from the platform operating the snubbing equipment. The casing from the well bore connected to the primary BOP broke causing the secondary BOP and the platform where the employee was working to fall to the ground approximately 28 feet below. The Axis Energy Services employee was hospitalized for a fractured leg. The Sundown Operating employee was assisting with the snubbing operation and was struck on the leg by the falling lug nut to the hydraulic BOP. The Sundown Operating employee was hospitalized for a fractured hip.

An employee was using a crane to set concrete blocks for a concrete footing. The crane came into close proximity with overhead power lines and two employees were electrically shocked and hospitalized.

Two employees were installing pre-cast concrete floor panels. The concrete floor panels collapsed onto the lower floor when the brackets and/or screws that secured the brackets into the wall failed. Both employees were hospitalized with blunt force trauma injuries.

Two employees were working on a 2-ton furnace lid that was suspended by a crane. The eye bolt broke, causing the lid to fall and land on the employees. One employee suffered a crushed abdomen and pelvis; the other suffered broken ribs.

Two employees were working in close proximity to a paving machine that was attached to a dump truck. When the dump bed was elevated, it contacted overhead electrical wires. The two employees were hospitalized for electrical burns.

Employee 1 and Employee 2 were working on a pulverizer breaker when Employee 1 made contact with the energized parts. Employee 1 suffered burns to their upper body and face, while Employee 2 suffered additional burns.
Two employees were performing maintenance on a hydrolyzer when steam released. Both employees were hospitalized with burns.
An employee tripped on a stand while placing goods on a pallet. She fell to the floor and suffered a broken femur. She was hospitalized.
An employee of Bobs Concrete was struck by the boom of a concrete pumping truck after the truck's outrigger shifted. The employee suffered a broken collarbone and a hand laceration.

After tearing up flooring (including carpet, laminate, and plywood) in a living room that an AC unit had flooded with water, two employees developed burns and rashes. Both employees were hospitalized.

Two employees were attaching a tie-in wire to hold a wire to a new insulator that had been put on a pole. The tie ware came into contact with the pole grounding wire, causing an arc flash that burned the employees' faces, arms, and necks.
